title: Too early to celebrate a victory over COVID-19 | Sheneman
body: Stretch for it.It’s tough to strike a balance when writing about COVID-19. I want to highlight the positives — vaccination rates, efficacy, etc. — while at the same time letting people know it’s not over yet. The end result is that you end up sounding like an insufferable doomsayer.We’re at the goal line, we can see the light at the end of the tunnel — pick whichever cliche you like — but we’re close to coming out the other side of this. It’s now a race between the variants and our ability to get people vaccinated and thankfully, we’re sticking needles in arms at a greater rate than we expected. Turns out a baseline of competence at the top makes a huge difference.Here’s the party pooper part: Despite the accelerating vaccine rates many more people are going to die before this is over. Seeing the finish line isn’t the same as crossing it. In Super Bowl XXVII Cowboys defensive lineman Leon Lett recovered a fumble at his own 35 and set to running it the length of the field for the presumptive touchdown only to have Buffalo wide receiver Don Bebee chase him down from behind and smack the ball out of his hand before Lett broke the plane of the goal line. Lett, an otherwise tremendous player, would fail to score and be forced to live down the embarrassment for the rest of his career. The Cowboys won anyway (Boo!) but the lesson remains the same: Score first, celebrate later.Note to readers: if you purchase something through one of our affiliate links we may earn a commission.
